Moths, dragonflies, and butterflies are metamorphic creatures that, despite their visually flimsy allure and delicate nature, evolve and grow as they shift and change. I feel like they are a very apt metaphor for Sansa Stark, who, through her pain due to her fragile place in society as a woman, is never broken entirely. She only evolves and grows as she shifts and changes through self realization. (x)

Moths especially are also creatures that employ camouflage in order to hide from predators and can thus be said to signify adaptability, which is certainly a character trait that Sansa possesses - as she tries to avoid drawing attention to herself at Joffrey’s court.

Throughout the show, Sansa constantly has to adapt to her circumstances. She evolves continually - and like a dragonfly/moth/butterfly she repeatedly emerges from one chrysalis after the other - often signaled by a radical change of style in her costume. As the story progresses the stylistic changes becomes more and more marked whereas they are more subtle and gradual during the early seasons.

A GILDED CAGE - SANSA’S WEDDING GOWN

While all the costumes are narratively important in Game of Thrones, some costumes carry a greater narrative weight than others, often because they are loaded with symbolic value. This is the case of Sansa’s wedding dress in season 3 since this garment is meant to be a visual manifestation of the way that the Lannisters take ownership of Sansa (and her claim to Winterfell) through her forced marriage to Tyrion Lannister. When talking about this particular costume designer Michele Clapton and embroiderer Michele Carragher both repeatedly use words like “caught”, “entrapment”, “domination” and “ownership”:

When Sansa is married against her will into the Lannister family, her dress shows her family’s sigil, the dire wolf, losing out to the Lannister’s, the lion. “It’s like she has been caught,” explains Clapton. (Michele Clapton, FastCompany)

There’s always a movement, particularly in Sansa, where you always see which way she’s being pulled. Her wedding to Tyrion where she has a girdle that wraps around her body which tells a story of entrapment by the Lannisters, which I thought was important, and a stamp on the back of her neck that stamps her as a Lannister. (Michele Clapton, TIME)

The embroiderer Michele Carragher explains that:

“Obviously we imagined that the wedding dress has been commissioned by Cersei and the Lannisters for Sansa, and so the embroidery would have come from Cersei’s mind. We guessed that it wouldn’t be romantic or lovely and girly and pretty with dainty flowers, but a real strong message of dominance, saying that we own you now, Sansa. (Michele Carragher,  Winter Is Coming)

This wedding dress is meant to be seen as a trap - a visual representation of the gilded cage that Sansa’s marriage to Tyrion really is.

Silhouette, Fabric and Colour

Compared to the rest of her season 3 costumes, it immediately becomes clear just how glaringly different the wedding dress is from the sleek, purple dresses with the trailing sleeves that Sansa wears throughout the season. There’s a reason for this stark difference between the costumes because whereas Sansa’s purple dresses signal her removal from the influence of Cersei, the wedding dress is a statement of Lannister dominance over her person and her body. The embroidery plays an especially important role in this context but I’ll return to that subject of the embroidery later on. First I want to take closer look on the general silhouette of the dress as well as the fabric and the colour - because these elements also carry meaning.

This dress is a sort of curious combination of the voluminous skirt and a tight sleeveless bodice, which gives the whole ensemble a slightly unbalanced look. The skirt is wider and more voluminous than what is seen on other female characters at the royal court, so this isn’t a dress that conforms to the local style. The skirt looks to be supported by some kind of armature underneath, very like the panniers at the hips that were used to create width in the skirts during the rococo style of the 18th century.

The skirt also has a bit of a train and with the sleeveless bodice, the overall effect is of a dress that is a bit bottom-heavy. The aesthetics of the gown is just slightly off and that is intentional. The lack of sleeves is an especially important detail according to the embroiderer:

For this dress, Michelle wanted it to be a confined, restricted bodice shape with bare, vulnerable arms. She wanted an embroidered band that would wrap around the bodice and tell Sansa’s life story. (Michele Carragher, Winter Is Coming)

Thus, the lack of sleeves is meant to signify vulnerability, the bodice itself tight and restrictive, trapping Sansa in her dress. The skirt itself is a bit curious in that regard - @caesarscat suggests that it is meant to create a more womanly shape for a bride that is still a child, and that is certainly a possibility. However, the volume of the skirt and the amount of fabric used (heavy brocade) must also make this dress heavy to walk in - it physically weighs her down as an external embodiment of how this whole situation weighs so heavily on her emotions.

The skirt also sports a very curious detail that contradicts the vulnerability of the bare arms. The panniers of dress is enhanced with pieces of metal (looks like bronze) with a chased pattern of plant-like arabesques. 

This is eerily similar to Cersei’s armoured dress from season 2. Cersei literally wore armour when she felt threatened and thus these pieces of metal also evoke Sansa’s dictum of Courtesy is a lady’s armour. So while the dress primarily works as a bodily trap, restricting Sansa’s movements and metaphorically exposing her vulnerable position, it also contains this tiny hint of Sansa’s preferred form of passive resistance: Her use of politesse as a form of emotional armour where she keeps people at arms length, refusing to let them see how she feels - a technique she uses on Tyrion in the scene right before the wedding ceremony.

I’ve previously pointed out how Sansa’s season 3 costumes signal a remove from the Lannister influence, particularly Cersei’s. The wedding dress is a conspicuous re-assertion of that influence, but now in the form of dominance rather than emulation. The deep purple colours have been replaced with a shiny, gold-accented brocade very like the fabrics used for Cersei’s and Joffrey’s costumes.

The fastening of the bodice has also reverted to the side-flap that characterized her kimono dresses, which were emulating Cersei’s season 1 look.

At the same time, the wedding dress contains a very subtle callback to Sansa’s Tourney dress from season one since the base colour of the gold-accented brocade is a pale lavender very similar to the season 1 dress. In a way, the use of the lavender colour is a cruel appropriation of this romantic dress (which incidentally also sports an embroidered direwolf like the wedding dress). The Tourney dress represent Sansa’s romanticism and her love of Chivalric Romance (x) - but now that romanticism has been put into a golden Lannister cage where marriage is not a union of lovers but a cynic power move against her family.

Another thing I noticed upon my re-watch of the wedding scene is how Sansa’s dress visually matches Joffrey’s opulent costume in terms of both colour and fabric. I’ve previously written about how matching clothes can be used to convey political and familial unity in the case of the Tyrells. In this case, however, the visual match between Sansa’s and Joffrey’s costumes signals domination rather than unity. 

In this context, the way that Sansa’s and Tyrion’s costumes don’t match is also meaningful. While Sansa is wearing gold-and-lavender brocade, Tyrion is wearing a tunic in oxblood leather. They clash visually, standing next to each other at the altar. However, after Sansa has been garbed in the red-gold Lannister bridal cloak, the dark red accent of the cloak suddenly makes her costume match Tyrion’s. Once again, this is not a visual statement of unity but rather of domination. With the cloaking of the bride, Tyrion (and through him House Lannister) takes possession of Sansa. She is now their property, bound to them permanently through the bonds of matrimony.

Sansa’s wedding costume also includes another element that harks back to her earlier romantic self - the lion medallion that Joffrey gave her as a love token in season 1 (he was insincere but to Sansa it was a gesture straight out of the chivalric romances she loved so much). Now this symbol of romantic love has been subverted into yet another message of domination, of ownership.

Embroidery

As we can see, the shape, the fabric and the colour of a costume can carry a lot of meaning. However, Clapton adds yet another narrative layer in the form of an embroidered band that wraps around the bodice and acts as a symbolic cage in the same manner that the dress itself functions as a material cage that envelops and restricts Sansa’s body. Clapton uses embroidery extensively in her costume design as a narrative element:

“The embroidery is a subliminal way to tell someone’s story,” says Michele Clapton (Hollywood Reporter)

When it comes to the embroidery Clapton co-operates with the embroiderer Michele Carragher, who creates countless beaded embellishments for the costumes of the show. In the case of Sansa’s wedding dress, Clapton and Carragher designed a piece of embroidery that uses the heraldry of several noble Houses to tell the story of Sansa’s parentage and her subsequent entrapment by the Lannisters. Thus, the entire piece makes up a story in itself, written across the body of an unwilling child-bride. 

“Obviously we imagined that the wedding dress has been commissioned by Cersei and the Lannisters for Sansa, and so the embroidery would have come from Cersei’s mind. We guessed that it wouldn’t be romantic or lovely and girly and pretty with dainty flowers, but a real strong message of dominance, saying that we own you now, Sansa. (Carragher, Winter Is Coming)

The story starts at the back of the band with a symbolic representation of Sansa’s parentage:

“For the wedding band, I started at the back of the waist with some Stark direwolves and Tully fish entwined that represent Sansa’s parentage.”  (Carragher, Winter Is Coming)

The band cross over itself on the front of the bodice where Carragher added the Lannister lion to the unfolding narrative:

“Then, as we move to the side, the Lannister lion is tangling with the direwolf and emerging on top, representing Sansa being seduced and then controlled by members of the house of Lannister. As it moves up the center, there’s a central ascending lion that’s got a Baratheon-like crown, a nod to Joffrey’s parentage.” (Carragher, Winter Is Coming) 

The story culminates at the back of her neck where the band morphs into a high and stiff collar, that looks rather uncomfortable:

“At the back neck, the Lannister lion is stamped onto it, representing how the Lannisters now have total ownership over this girl who was once a Stark.”  (Carragher, Winter Is Coming)


This is an ostentatious mark of ownership - Clapton herself calls it a “stamp” but one could just as well call it a “brand”. It is a symbolic marking of ownership - a statement of domination that has all the subtlety of a sledgehammer to the face.

The Pomegranate

Apart from the heraldic sigils of Houses Stark, Tully and Lannister, Michele Carragher also includes another symbol: the Pomegranate. 

The dress colour was still very much Sansa Stark and the embroidery had pale golden tones but woven through the story are ripe red pomegranates, the red colour symbolising the growing Lannister influence over her. (Michele Carragher)

Carragher interprets the deep red colour of the pomegranates as a symbol of Lannister influence due to the colour - and it looks as though she’s used either garnets or ruby swarovski crystals for the beaded embroidery.

I find Carragher’s interpretation rather curious because the pomegranate is one of the most ancient symbols in the world and it is invested with religious meaning in a great many cultures - from the ancient cities of Sumer to Judaism, Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam and Christianity. The oldest depiction of the pomegranate in the arts date was found in the city of Uruk in ancient Sumer and dates back more than 5,000 years (x). It was connected to the cult of Ishtar/Innana, goddess of love, sex, fertility.

Throughout the Mediterranean, Near Eastern and Middle Eastern world, the pomegranate has been revered as an ancient and potent symbol of fertility, regeneration and marriage:

“People use whatever is at hand to express their religious beliefs,"says Frank A. Salamone, an authority on religious symbols and a professor at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y. Centuries ago, in the Fertile Crescent, where so many religions arose, the pomegranate was at hand. By its very nature, it lent itself to religious symbolism.

"The pomegranate is red, and so is blood,” Salamone says. “It has a lot of seeds and is an obvious symbol of fertility.” It’s beautiful, strong and delicate, and its juice has healing properties, he says. “It says a lot of different things all at once. People bring meaning to it.” (Prof. Frank A. Salamone)

The pomegranate tree is considered to have originated in the in Persia (Iran) and its connection with notions of fertility is intimately connected with the advent and spread of agriculture. It’s status as a symbol of fertility was most likely transmitted through a kind of cross-cultural pollination along with the tree as it was exported East to China and West to Egypt, Turkey, North Africa, Greece and Rome.

While it is a fertility symbol in many cultures, the fruit also became associated with Death and Resurrection in Greek and Roman mythology. Most famously in the myth of Persephone, daughter of the fertility goddess Demeter. Persephone was a vegetation goddess like Demeter but according to myth she was abducted by Hades, the God of the Underworld. Demeter went into mourning and all plant life died so Zeus commanded Hades to release her daughter. However, Hades had tricked Persephone into eating six pomegranate seeds and so she was forced to spend six months of the year as Queen of the Underworld and the remaining six months above ground as a goddess of spring. The myth of Persephone is essentially an allegorical retelling of the changing of the seasons - and thus the pomegranate is not just connected to fertility (spring) but also to death (winter) and resurrection (the re-emergence of spring).

However, the pomegranate as a symbol of death and resurrection is also connected to another mythical figure: Adonis, the lover of Venus, the Roman goddess of love and sex. In the Metamorphoses, the Roman poet Ovid recounts the tale of Adonis who is slain on a hunt and the grief-stricken Venus creates the anemone flower, red like a pomegranate in memory of him:

When from the heights she saw the lifeless body lying in its own blood, she leapt down, tearing her clothes, and tearing at her hair as well, and beat at her breasts with fierce hands, complaining to the fates. “And yet not everything is in your power” she said. “Adonis, there shall be an everlasting token of my grief, and every year an imitation of your death will complete a re-enactment of my mourning. But your blood will be changed into a flower…” So saying, she sprinkled the blood with odorous nectar: and, at the touch, it swelled up, as bubbles emerge in yellow mud. In less than an hour, a flower, of the colour of blood, was created such as pomegranates carry, that hide their seeds under a tough rind. But enjoyment of it is brief: for, lightly clinging, and too easily fallen, the winds deflower it, which are likewise responsible for its name, windflower: anemone’ (Source)

According to myth, Adonis was raised by Persephone in the Underworld - but the figure has much older roots in the Sumerian story of Innana and Dumuzid. Adonis is thus very likely connected to Dying-and-Rising archetype, which characterizes a number of male fertility gods in the Middle Eastern and Mediterranean region of during Antiquity.

Christianity also appropriated the symbolism of Fertility and Resurrection associated with the pomegranate into its iconography:

In Christian art the pomegranate, often split and showing the seeds, was interpreted as a symbol of fertility, hope of immortality, and the Resurrection. The infant Jesus is frequently seen in paintings and sculpture presenting the pomegranate to his mother. In the last of the famous Unicorn tapestries at The Cloisters the symbolic meaning of marriage and fertility is illustrated by showing the Unicorn chained to the pomegranate tree, with the red seeds of a bursting fruit spilling on him. (Hildegard Schneider)

So the pomegranates on Sansa’s wedding dress has a very old and rich symbolic history - and the connection between the pomegranate and fertility is very apt in this context since the Lannisters intend for Sansa to bear fruit in her marriage in the form of a Lannister-Stark child through which they can claim the North.

Even more interesting is the fact that Sansa has her very own pomegranate symbolism in GRRM’s text. After Petyr Baelish spirits Sansa away to the Fingers, he offers her pomegranates and other fruits during a private conversation where he’s imparting his particular brand of wisdom:

Grisel reappeared before he could say more, balancing a large platter. She set it down between them. There were apples and pears and pomegranates, some sad-looking grapes, a huge blood orange. The old woman had brought a round of bread as well, and a crock of butter. Petyr cut a pomegranate in two with his dagger, offering half to Sansa. “You should try and eat, my lady.” “Thank you, my lord.” Pomegranate seeds were so messy; Sansa chose a pear instead, and took a small delicate bite. It was very ripe. The juice ran down her chin.

…

“In King’s Landing, there are two sorts of people. The players and the pieces.”

“And I was a piece?” She dreaded the answer.

“Yes, but don’t let that trouble you. You’re still half a child. Every man’s a piece to start with, and every maid as well. Even some who think they are players.” He ate another seed. “Cersei, for one. She thinks herself sly, but in truth she is utterly predictable. Her strength rests on her beauty, birth, and riches. Only the first of those is truly her own, and it will soon desert her. I pity her then. She wants power, but has no notion what to do with it when she gets it. Everyone wants something, Alayne. And when you know what a man wants you know who he is, and how to move him." 

…

Lord Petyr dismissed him with a wave, and returned to the pomegranate again as Oswell shuffled down the steps. ”Tell me, Alayne—which is more dangerous, the dagger brandished by an enemy, or the hidden one pressed to your back by someone you never even see?“

"The hidden dagger.” (ASoS, Sansa VI) 

Baelish then starts to eat a blood orange as he continues to talk, steadily guiding Sansa through his machinations until she realizes that it was Olenna Tyrell who poisoned Joffrey:

He tilted his chin back and squeezed the blood orange, so the juice ran down into his mouth. “I love the juice but I loathe the sticky fingers,” he complained, wiping his hands. “Clean hands, Sansa. Whatever you do, make certain your hands are clean.” (ASoS, Sansa VI)

The conversation goes on as Baelish relates exactly how he manipulated the Tyrells into doing what he wanted.

This is not just a conversation over fruit where Baelish instructs his new pupil in the subtleties of the game of thrones. It is a temptation scenario where he offers Sansa a fruit associated with temptation as he intends to mold her into his own image. Like Hades, Baelish tempts Sansa with the pomegranate but unlike Persephone, Sansa refuses the fruit. 

Sansa REFUSES the pomegranate! This is very important because it foreshadows her eventually rejecting Baelish and his nefarious ambitions.

This temptation scenario is lent even more symbolic weight if we consider the hypothesis that the Forbidden Fruit in the Garden of Eden might not have been an apple but a pomegranate! (x) This interpretation is still somewhat controversial but if the Forbidden Fruit was indeed a pomegranate then the Temptation of Eve does have an interesting parallel with the Temptation of Persephone.

I have been unable to find any confirmation that the pomegranates on Sansa’s wedding dress are meant to have a deeper meaning than an association to the Lannister red. However, Carragher develops her creations in collaboration with Clapton and she does quite a bit of historical research:

For “Game of Thrones,” Carragher often spends as long thinking about a piece as she does making it. First, she confers with Clapton about each character’s narrative arc and the costumes Clapton has designed for them. Then Carragher does historical research in museums near her home, in East London. After a month of planning, she ships her materials to the show’s Belfast production studios, where she works six days a week, twelve hours a day, embellishing a season’s worth of costumes. (The NewYorker)

Thus, it is not implausible that adorning a wedding dress with an age old symbol of fertility and marriage is not entirely coincidental on the part of the designers!

trail.content_raw:
I’ve previously written a series of essays that analyse Sansa Stark’s narrative arc in Game of Thrones - during season 1 (Part 1, Part 2, Part 3, Part 4, Part 5, Part 6) and during season 2 (Part 7, Part 8, Part 9, Part 10) and now during season 3 (Part 11, Part 12, Part 13, Part 14, Part 15, Part 16). This post is the 17th installment in this series and the last one that deals with Sansa’s season 3 arc. 

In this post, I’m going to take a closer look at Sansa’s costumes during the season with a special emphasis on her spectacular golden wedding gown since her season 3 arc revolves around her political value as Robb’s heir apparent and there are several plots aimed at securing the Key to the North through marriage. It is also a costume that is inscribed with a lot of narrative and symbolic meaning that subtly enriches her story and her characterization.

Costume design is an integral aspect of the visual language of cinema and television - and especially on Game of Thrones since costume designer Michele Clapton approaches the costumes in terms of story-telling.

I always try to make the clothes visually tell something. (FIDM Museum Blog)

I always try to tell that story — the costumes for me are narrative and you should be able to look at them [the characters] and understand where they are mentally in their journey. (Insider)

I love to try and indicate the emotional state of characters through their costumes, and also to indicate their influence over other characters and courts. Sometimes this says so much more than words. (SPIN)

Thus, the costumes are incredibly important in this show and it is worth paying attention to them because every single detail is meaningful:

Everything – even a fashion choice – has meaning on “Game of Thrones.” In this cutthroat world where men fight for the Iron Throne and the women yield a different kind of power, a choice of fabric or a different cut of cloth can be a political statement, costume designer Michele Clapton told TODAY.com.(Today)

Even in real life, clothing has always had symbolic and communicative value through which people signal social and cultural positions. In short, fashion and dress codes place people within a given culture. Garments function as non-verbal signs that that can be interpreted differently depending on the context, situation or culture (x). That is doubly so for costume design since it its entire raison d’etre is to support and enrich the story that is told.

[[MORE]]

THE SARTORIAL EVOLUTION OF SANSA STARK

As said, Sansa’s golden wedding dress will be the primary focus of this post - both because of its symbolic value but also because it is markedly different from the rest of her costumes during season 3. However, before I start analyzing the wedding dress it will be instructive to take a look at how she generally dresses during season 3 because the colour, cut and embellishment of the wedding dress stands in stark contrast to the rest of her costumes.

The costumes are an important part of the story-telling but they are an especially important part of Sansa’s character since she’s the only character that is repeatedly shown to make her own clothes! This is something that Michele Clapton emphasizes in several interviews:

“She expresses herself through her ability to embroider and stitch,” Clapton told Buzzfeed. “We’ve always used that as something that Sansa expresses her feelings through—her embroidery and depictions on her costumes, and through shade and color.” (Looper)

Costume is important to Sansa—she sees it as a way of communicating with people, to show her aspirations. And we very quickly see her develop.She starts to adapt—she has certain people she’s impressed by. (TIME)

So let’s take a closer look at Sansa Stark’s season 3 costumes - both in relation to where she is politically and emotionally in season 3 but also in relation to how her costumes have evolved from season 1. 

Season 1

When we first meet Sansa Stark in Winterfell, her costumes reflect both her Northern roots with the heavy fabrics, the sensible layers that insulates against the cold climate (like the linen shirt underneath the dress), the embroidery that the Northern women practice to while away the time - as well as her youthful innocence, which is very much reflected in the use of the baby blue colour that dominate almost all of her Northern costumes. 

Clapton chose dark blue as a common element in the Stark costumes, which reflect the harsher Northern climate:

We have a lot of blues and grays, murkier colors that seemed right for the harsh northern climates. The Starks represent a warm family unit, so the blues of their costumes are rather warm. But within the family, the various personalities are reflected in what they wear. For example, Sansa is in a slightly cooler blue. (CostumeVault) 

Interestingly, Clapton also uses this light blue as a way to emphasize that Sansa is somewhat out of sync with the rest of her family. This becomes especially clear when the Starks line up to greet King Robert in the first episode. While the rest of the Starks are dressed in dark blues and greys, Sansa is exclusively dressed in the light baby blue - even the fur on her cloak is light blue! This makes Sansa stand out like a sore thumb among the Stark household. Considering how Clapton approaches costume design in terms of both story-telling and characterization, this choice is no coincidence.

She is, in a sense, a bit isolated within in her own family given how none of her siblings share her interests, not to mention that gender norms also play a role in relation to this issue (x). While this isn’t something that the show really delves into at the level of the text, the costuming clearly articulates a sense of isolation within the family when it comes to Sansa - and that is probably one of the reasons why she’s so excited to travel to King’s Landing.

Sansa’s costumes changes when she arrives in King’s Landing. A significant costume is the lavender dress that she first wears at the Hand’s Tourney. This dress represents a sartorial amalgam of the Northern and the King’s Landing style. The lavender colour occupy a mid-point between Sansa’s Northern blue and the dusty rose colours that the women wear at the court in King’s Landing. However, the fabric is similar to her Northern dress and the embroidery not only includes her House Sigil (the Direwolf) but the leafy vines that climb the sides of the dress are rather similar to the embroidery on her Winterfell feast dress (picture at the far right in the collage below)

The most conspicuous detail is the neckline, which is not only significantly lower than her Northern dresses but it is also embellished with cloth roses - an completely new element in Sansa’s personal iconography (x). This dress also marks the beginning of Sansa’s slow transition from a child to a young girl at the cusp of maidenhood.

Later in the season, Sansa’s Northern dresses are completely discarded - and she is now dressed in the kimono-style of light-weight fabric like the ones that Cersei wears.

However, it is also important to note that she only starts wearing these Cersei-inspired costumes after she has fallen completely within the power of the Lannisters.

Where a character comes from is indicated through the color and cut of the costume. When we first see Sansa [Sophie Turner], she wears things in a Stark way — very well, but they are slightly clumsy and the cloth is rather homespun. As she comes to King’s Landing, her progression is influenced by Cersei [Lena Headey] and her costumes shift. After Cersei does the awful thing of sanctioning the death of Ned Stark [Sansa’s father], Sansa is stuck — you can see her frozen in time. She’s looking like someone who has just killed her father. And then we will see her progression as she slowly withdraws from the look. (LATimes) 

A very important detail of these Cersei-like costumes is the fact that they don’t fit Sansa at all! They are much too large and she’s practically drowning in them. This is a very important detail:

“A lot of people said her costume doesn’t fit. Well, of course it doesn’t! She’s a young girl trying to copy someone,” explained Clapton. “Not everyone wears things brilliantly or beautifully, or has the access to do that. I think it’s really important that some things don’t fit. Some things are slightly odd.” (FastCompany)

Sansa is not only trying to copy someone much older but she’s also wearing these garments at a point in the story where she’s cut adrift from her family - her father is imprisoned and her sister is missing. She is completely at the mercy of the Lannisters - utterly dependent on their “mercy” while she at the same time desperately tries to save her father. It is no coincidence that she’s wearing her blue kimono dress when she publicly begs for her father’s life and the rose kimono-dress at his public confession (that she thought would save his life) as well as later on when Joffrey forces her to look at Ned Stark’s severed head. 

When a costume is worn within the narrative is just as important as how it looks.

Season 2

Sansa has a fewer costumes in season 2. Whereas she had 8 different costumes in season 1, now she has 4 costumes - and two of those are repeats from the former season, which also reflects that she is no longer a privileged young noble with many new dresses. She starts the season in her two kimono dresses - this conforms to a pattern of Clapton’s where she has a character wear a costume from the latter part of the previous season in the early part of the new season (x) This serves create narrative continuity at the visual level.

This pattern also serves to express the emotional journey of the character.

I try to tell stories through the characters and certain characters move more in their costumes to tell their story whereas others, by not changing, tell their story. One doesn’t change or one does and it actually almost heightens the difference in them. I spend hours designing costumes, so much of my time is spent plotting the route. What would she wear in this situation and how can we get here there elegantly from this situation? Plotting the costumes is so important and so essential to the story for me, especially in a show like Game of Thrones, where you’re constantly shifting to other people’s stories, so it’s knowing when to move them forward. (TIME)

During the season, Sansa’s to kimono dresses are destroyed as they are quite literally torn off her body - one when she’s beaten by the King’s Guard (x) and the other during the assault she suffers in the Bread Riots (x). Then we see her in a light blue nightgown that is later paired with a light blue house coat.

Interestingly, this house coat is embellished with a leaf-and-vine motif, which is associated with her Northern costumes in season 1 as well as the lavender dress, which is a sartorial representation of Sansa trying to adapt to Southern fashion whilst retaining her northern roots.

This connection to her her roots and her home is also subtly represented through the embroidery on Sansa’s nightgown. It is a bit difficult to see but her nightgown is embellished with little white flowers and curling vines - and they are pretty much identical to the embroidery that decorates the light blue dress that Sansa wears in Winterfell in her very first appearance on the show.

All costume details are important on this show but WHEN a costume is worn is also important. Thus, it is not surprising that Sansa’s leisure wear represents her Stark identity. These are garments that she wears in the privacy of her chambers. She may wear Southern style dress in court, but in private she wears garments that remind her of her home. The fact that she wears a garment connected to her home and her childhood in the scene where she gets her first period is also significant. The onset of menses is part of her physical maturation, she is no longer a child in the eyes of some people - and in the very next scene, she and Cersei discuss motherhood. 

After this scene, her fashion style changes dramatically. Her final costume in season 2 is radically different from the earlier ones - both in colour and in shape. Sansa debuts a dress in a deep purple patterned with wine-leaves, with long trailing sleeves and paired with a golden belt. It fits her much better than the previous kimono dresses and it closed in the front but opens at the neckline and the skirt to showcase an under-dress or a long scarf.

This is not the dress of a child but of a young woman. However, this style also signals a conscious removal from the style of Cersei but neither is it a retreat into the style of her childhood. This dress is extremely similar to what Sansa’s mother Catelyn Stark wears - it is, in fact, the exact same silhouette as the gowns worn by the Lady Stark. She has also changed her hair style.

In season 1, Sansa started to adopt the intricate hairstyles made popular by Cersei Lannister - it is even directly commented on by Septa Mordane.

During season 2, Sansa still wears her hair in this way when she’s in public. However, in the episode of the Battle of the Blackwater, Sansa debuts a whole new style, both in dress and in the way she wears her hair, in public - and like her dress, Sansa’s new hair style is modelled on her mother.

It isn’t completely identical but the basic elements are the same: the side-locks are pulled away from the face, slight twisted and fastened behind the head. With Sansa, they are just tied together much lower than they are with Catelyn. 

In short, towards the end of season 2, Sansa’s costumes and hair styling represents her rejection of Cersei as a model of influence, instead choosing to style herself like her mother. In terms of narrative, I find it interesting that Sansa sports this brand new style in a scene where Cersei acts like a mentor towards her, trying to impart her own toxic brand of wisdom (x). In the books, Sansa rejects Cersei’s “wisdom” internally but since we don’t get that inner monologue on the screen, the it is left to the costuming to visually express this rejection rejection of Cersei’s influence.

Season 3

In season 3, the purple dress with the wine-leaf pattern not only makes a re-appearance, it also serves as the template for the rest of Sansa’s wardrobe, apart from her wedding dress, which is in a radically different style than the rest of her season 3 dresses.

Apart from her wedding dress, all of Sansa’s costumes are in various shades of purple. They also adhere to the same cut - a slender silhouette with long, trailing sleeves. They close at the front, just under the bust, which leaves space for a peak at a patterned underskirt. 

As I’ve mentioned above, this style of dress is exactly like the gowns her mother wear. In fact, Catelyn Stark wears a similar dress in the exact same fabric but in a different colour!

In general, Sansa’s season 3 costumes also marks a beginning towards a darker palette. Whereas she wore garments in light blues, light lavender and light rose during seasons 1-2, in season 3 almost all of her dresses fall within the darker spectrum of the purple colours like dark magenta, amethyst and blue violet. Clapton likes to use colour symbolically:

According to Clapton, color plays a pivotal role in foreshadowing characters’ futures. “We do all these sort of secret symbols, color hints about the ways the court is being influenced,” says Clapton.” They are just little things that people may not notice unless they really look.“ We asked for examples but got no specifics. Instead Clapton hints again: “You can see the people who are getting the power by the way the court starts to dress. It’s just a small thing, a color here and there and it slowly escalates. I think it’s really important to do that because people tend to watch these episodes over and over again and later on box sets. So it’s important that you don’t get everything on the first viewing.”(The Hollywood Reporter)

So I can’t help but wonder what Sansa’s dark purple dresses are meant to signify. In terms of colour theory, purple is an intermediate colour between red and blue, and in this context it is interesting that the two women who exerts the most influence over Sansa wears either deep red (Cersei) or light blue (Margaery). So the purple of Sansa’s gowns may signal that she’s influenced by very different people:

“She’s still young and vulnerable–she’s always influenced by the people around her,” Clapton said. “Without saying too much, she befriends someone new. She starts to dress a bit like her–so she’s still being pulled and influenced and she’s not really her own person yet.” (Fashionista)

However, the colour purple also has a number of symbolic meanings. In some cultures purple is associated with death, mourning and endurance of suffering - and that certainly fits well with Sansa’s narrative arc so far. But the colour purple also has a long history as a sign of wealth, luxury and royalty! The association between purple and royalty is particularly interesting in this case because season 3 includes a detail about Sansa that may foreshadow her becoming royalty, i.e. the ringing of the bells at her birth (x). Speaking of the use of colour as foreshadowing, I would be amiss not to mention the infamous Purple Wedding that takes place in season 4 and in which Sansa unwittingly plays a part by carrying a poison in the form of amethyst crystals. Incidentally, she wears purple at that feast as well.

While Sansa dresses like her mother in a visual repudiation of Cersei Lannister, her appearance is also subtly influenced by a new person in her orbit.

Queen-to-be Margaery Tyrell befriends Sansa, first in order to learn what kind of person Joffrey is (x) and later as part of a plot to marry Sansa to her brother Loras Tyrell in an effort to secure Sansa’s claim to Winterfell for House Tyrell (x).

Thus, after Margaery has made friends with Sansa (and after the secret bethrothal has been agreed up), Sansa begins to wear her hair like her new friend. Petyr Baelish notices this and comments upon it when Sansa politely rejects his offer to spirit her away from the capital. This is, incidentally, the second time that the style of Sansa’s hair is directly referred to in the show - because when it comes to Sansa, her hair styles always communicate something! Here, it subtly signals her new alliance with the Tyrells (as well as Margaery’s growing influence over the royal court). Throughout the seasons, we’ll see how not only Sansa’s clothes but also her hair is inscribed with meaning.

DRAGONFLIES, BUTTERFLIES AND MOTHS - SANSA’S PERSONAL ICONOGRAPHY

Michele Clapton’s costume design is, as said, always narratively important - and every little detail has meaning:

“People don’t necessarily see this,” admitted Clapton. But, it’s still worth the work: “For us, it’s to have that depth in all of the costumes. Even if you look really closely there is something telling you something about this person,” she added. (FastCompany)

This is especially important when it comes to embellishments and accessories. Clapton almost always uses jewellery and embroidery symbolically - the most obvious examples being Cersei’s lion embossed necklaces and lion embroidered gowns to Daenerys’ dragon jewels and scaly embellishments and Margaery’s delicate roses. 

Sansa also has her own personal iconography, which is expressed through the embroidery on her clothes and the jewellery she wears. However, (unlike Cersei, Daenerys and Margaery), Sansa’s personal iconography in the early seasons are not rooted in her House sigil (though the direwolf does grace one of her season 1 dresses). Thus, her iconography is more about Sansa’s personal journey rather than her family identity, which is also her political identity - though this changes during the later seasons. This reflects both Sansa’s initial desire to leave her family home, to become part of a larger world but later on, it can also be seen as an expression of how her political/familial identity becomes a liability for her at Joffrey’s court where she is brutally punished for her brother’s victories. In this context, it is noteworthy that the Stark direwolves only make a brief appearance on her clothing when she is forcibly married to Tyrion Lannister - and here, her familial/political identity is exploited by the enemies of her house.The Stark direwolf only makes a definitive return in season 6 and 7 when Sansa has finally escaped her enemies and embarks upon a quest to reclaim her family seat, emerging victorious as the Lady of Winterfell. 

In that sense, the withholding of the Stark direwolf from her costuming is just as meaningful as Clapton’s choice to withhold the Targaryen red from Daenerys’ costumes until season 7 (x).

Sansa’s personal iconography during the early seasons consists primarily of three symbols: the Dragonfly, the Butterfly and the Moth, though the Rose makes a very brief appearance in one of her season 1 dresses: the lavender Tourney dress that is very much connected with her romanticism and her love for the ideals of Chilvaric romance (I’ve covered that subject here). However, unlike the Rose, the Moth, the Butterfly and the Dragonfly remain consistent symbols within Sansa’s personal iconography across 5 seasons.The question is: what do these animals represent in relation to Sansa’s character and her narrative arc?

The Dragonfly

The Dragonfly is, IMO, Sansa’s primary symbol during the early seasons since it is the one she wears the most. The first time we see Sansa associated with the Dragonfly is in the second episode of season 1 where the Starks and the royal family are travelling on the King’s Road towards King’s Landing. Here, the dragonfly appears in the form of a delicate silver necklace.

Later in season 1, the dragonfly also appears on Sansa’s light blue kimono dress, which she wears when she pleads for her father’s life. This dress reappears in season 2, when she wears it during her dinner with Cersei, Myrcella and Tommen (x) and in the scene where Joffrey has her publicly beaten (x), along with the necklace. The dress is destroyed in that scene - but the dragonfly necklace reappears over seasons 1-3 until it is left behind in season 4.

So what does the Dragonfly symbolise? This is where we have to be careful in our interpretations because when it comes to symbolism, multiple meanings exists, which all comes down to different cultural contexts. Thus, the dragonfly is generally a positive symbol in Eastern and Native American folklore where it is associated with courage, strength, good luck and happiness. In European folklore and etymology, however, the dragonfly has more negative associations where it is associated with witchcraft as well as elves and fairies (x). These negative association was apparently due to its shape:

The reason why dragonflies inspire for the most part, negative myths, is believed to be due to their body shape which looks like a needle at the end (in fact, one of their nicknames is ‘Devil’s Darning Needle’), their erratic flight patterns and their shimmering wings. (x)

Then there’s New Age philosophy, which has given the dragonfly new, primarily positive and spiritual connotations like hope, change and love (x). What is especially interesting in the context of GRRM’s story is the fact that dragonflies were also associated with dragons in Western folklore:

One of the earliest reference to the name ‘dragonfly’ is on the book Sylva Sylvarum, or a Naturall Historie: In Ten Centuries (Classic Reprint) by Francis Bacon – an indeed fascinating read on ancient teachings, observations and experiments. Even though we can’t be 100% sure, it’s widely believed that Bacon picked up on a very common folklore name that was used at the time. And this should come as no surprise as dragonflies were widely used in folklore throughout the world and it was believed that they once were dragons. (x)

Within the universe that GRRM has established for his story, there is a historical character called the Prince of Dragonflies, Duncan Targaryen who gave up the throne for the love. The Prince of Dragonflies and his lady love, Jenny of Oldstones, is the subject of at least one romantic song - and in this respect the dragonfly is connected with the songs of romance that the young and innocent Sansa loves so dearly. Does this mean that Sansa’s dragonfly motif in the show is meant to refer to the story of the Prince of Dragonflies? I honestly don’t know. While Michele Clapton has read the books (x) and spoken with GRRM (x), I haven’t been able to find any quotes of hers about Sansa’s dragonflies.

Since Michele Clapton hasn’t spoken about her use of the dragonfly motif, it is important to be careful when ascribing it a specific symbolic meaning. However, in general, the dragonfly is most often associated with transformation since it is a metamorphic creature that undergoes a pupate stage before it emerges in its adult form with the beautiful iridescent wings. The dragonfly as a symbol of transformation is incredibly apt when it comes to the narrative arc of Sansa Stark - she is constantly forced to adapt and change by external circumstances. At the same time the fragile beauty of the adult dragonfly is also a very fitting image for Sansa’s youthful beauty when she’s a captive in the early seasons. The dragonfly as a general symbol of transformation is also supported by the use of moths and butterflies as secondary symbols in her personal iconography.

If the dragonfly mainly symbolizes transformation in Sansa’s personal iconography then it is no coincidence that the symbol first appear after she’s left Winterfell - since this is really the point where her narrative journey starts to gain momentum. This is this very beginning of first transformation; from Northern girl to Southern lady - but that is just the first of her many transformations.

The Moth and the Butterfly

Moths and butterflies are secondary symbols in Sansa’s personal iconography. In season 1, Sansa wears ring in what looks to be the shape of a moth, at least the ragged edges of the wings suggest a moth rather than a butterfly.

In season 3, a necklace with either a butterfly or a moth motif is introduced - as are set of bodice clasps that either looks like moth wings or a type of helicopter seed pods (x).

If these claps are meant to represent helicopter seed pods rather than moth/butterfly wings, then the question is this: are they meant to be decorative or symbolic? And if they are symbolic, what do they symbolize? In general terms, seed pods represent the continuation of the life cycle of they tree they come from - they fly away, fall to the ground where they lie dormant during winter until it is time put forth the first tendrils of a new plant when spring arrives. So in a sense, the seed pods of Sansa’s claps can be said to signify growth and change just like the dragonfly.

The symbolism of both moths and butterflies varies vastly in accordance with cultural context - while there’s some overlap between certain cultures, other cultures ascribe these creatures very different meanings (x, x) - not to mention the meanings that New Age philosophy ascribes to these creatures (x). There is NO universal symbolism of the butterfly and the moth! Many of the meanings ascribed to them are culturally specific and it is important to be aware of this. I’m not going to list the various symbolic meanings because there are a lot of them. Moths and butterflies belong to the same family of insects (lepidoptera). While butterflies are primarily diurnal (active during the day), moths are predominantly noctural (active at night) or crepuscular (active at twilight). Moths and butterflies sometimes have contrasting symbolic meanings and sometimes synonymous symbolic meanings, all dependent on cultural context. 

However, in a very general sense, both moths and butterflies are symbols of transformation as they, like the dragonfly, are metamorphic creatures. 

They are also delicate and fragile. However, just like in the case of the dragonfly, Clapton hasn’t said anything about this motif - but considering that the certain parts of the symbolism of these winged creatures overlap with the dragonfly, I think it is safe to say that butterflies and moths serve the same symbolic function as the dragonfly - to signal metamorphosis and change. In this respect I agree completely with Freya Lilian Porteus:

Moths, dragonflies, and butterflies are metamorphic creatures that, despite their visually flimsy allure and delicate nature, evolve and grow as they shift and change. I feel like they are a very apt metaphor for Sansa Stark, who, through her pain due to her fragile place in society as a woman, is never broken entirely. She only evolves and grows as she shifts and changes through self realization. (x)

Moths especially are also creatures that employ camouflage in order to hide from predators and can thus be said to signify adaptability, which is certainly a character trait that Sansa possesses - as she tries to avoid drawing attention to herself at Joffrey’s court.

Throughout the show, Sansa constantly has to adapt to her circumstances. She evolves continually - and like a dragonfly/moth/butterfly she repeatedly emerges from one chrysalis after the other - often signaled by a radical change of style in her costume. As the story progresses the stylistic changes becomes more and more marked whereas they are more subtle and gradual during the early seasons.

A GILDED CAGE - SANSA’S WEDDING GOWN

While all the costumes are narratively important in Game of Thrones, some costumes carry a greater narrative weight than others, often because they are loaded with symbolic value. This is the case of Sansa’s wedding dress in season 3 since this garment is meant to be a visual manifestation of the way that the Lannisters take ownership of Sansa (and her claim to Winterfell) through her forced marriage to Tyrion Lannister. When talking about this particular costume designer Michele Clapton and embroiderer Michele Carragher both repeatedly use words like “caught”, “entrapment”, “domination” and “ownership”:

When Sansa is married against her will into the Lannister family, her dress shows her family’s sigil, the dire wolf, losing out to the Lannister’s, the lion. “It’s like she has been caught,” explains Clapton. (Michele Clapton, FastCompany)

There’s always a movement, particularly in Sansa, where you always see which way she’s being pulled. Her wedding to Tyrion where she has a girdle that wraps around her body which tells a story of entrapment by the Lannisters, which I thought was important, and a stamp on the back of her neck that stamps her as a Lannister. (Michele Clapton, TIME)

The embroiderer Michele Carragher explains that:

“Obviously we imagined that the wedding dress has been commissioned by Cersei and the Lannisters for Sansa, and so the embroidery would have come from Cersei’s mind. We guessed that it wouldn’t be romantic or lovely and girly and pretty with dainty flowers, but a real strong message of dominance, saying that we own you now, Sansa. (Michele Carragher,  Winter Is Coming)

This wedding dress is meant to be seen as a trap - a visual representation of the gilded cage that Sansa’s marriage to Tyrion really is.

Silhouette, Fabric and Colour

Compared to the rest of her season 3 costumes, it immediately becomes clear just how glaringly different the wedding dress is from the sleek, purple dresses with the trailing sleeves that Sansa wears throughout the season. There’s a reason for this stark difference between the costumes because whereas Sansa’s purple dresses signal her removal from the influence of Cersei, the wedding dress is a statement of Lannister dominance over her person and her body. The embroidery plays an especially important role in this context but I’ll return to that subject of the embroidery later on. First I want to take closer look on the general silhouette of the dress as well as the fabric and the colour - because these elements also carry meaning.

This dress is a sort of curious combination of the voluminous skirt and a tight sleeveless bodice, which gives the whole ensemble a slightly unbalanced look. The skirt is wider and more voluminous than what is seen on other female characters at the royal court, so this isn’t a dress that conforms to the local style. The skirt looks to be supported by some kind of armature underneath, very like the panniers at the hips that were used to create width in the skirts during the rococo style of the 18th century.

The skirt also has a bit of a train and with the sleeveless bodice, the overall effect is of a dress that is a bit bottom-heavy. The aesthetics of the gown is just slightly off and that is intentional. The lack of sleeves is an especially important detail according to the embroiderer:

For this dress, Michelle wanted it to be a confined, restricted bodice shape with bare, vulnerable arms. She wanted an embroidered band that would wrap around the bodice and tell Sansa’s life story. (Michele Carragher, Winter Is Coming)

Thus, the lack of sleeves is meant to signify vulnerability, the bodice itself tight and restrictive, trapping Sansa in her dress. The skirt itself is a bit curious in that regard - @caesarscat suggests that it is meant to create a more womanly shape for a bride that is still a child, and that is certainly a possibility. However, the volume of the skirt and the amount of fabric used (heavy brocade) must also make this dress heavy to walk in - it physically weighs her down as an external embodiment of how this whole situation weighs so heavily on her emotions.

The skirt also sports a very curious detail that contradicts the vulnerability of the bare arms. The panniers of dress is enhanced with pieces of metal (looks like bronze) with a chased pattern of plant-like arabesques. 

This is eerily similar to Cersei’s armoured dress from season 2. Cersei literally wore armour when she felt threatened and thus these pieces of metal also evoke Sansa’s dictum of Courtesy is a lady’s armour. So while the dress primarily works as a bodily trap, restricting Sansa’s movements and metaphorically exposing her vulnerable position, it also contains this tiny hint of Sansa’s preferred form of passive resistance: Her use of politesse as a form of emotional armour where she keeps people at arms length, refusing to let them see how she feels - a technique she uses on Tyrion in the scene right before the wedding ceremony.

I’ve previously pointed out how Sansa’s season 3 costumes signal a remove from the Lannister influence, particularly Cersei’s. The wedding dress is a conspicuous re-assertion of that influence, but now in the form of dominance rather than emulation. The deep purple colours have been replaced with a shiny, gold-accented brocade very like the fabrics used for Cersei’s and Joffrey’s costumes.

The fastening of the bodice has also reverted to the side-flap that characterized her kimono dresses, which were emulating Cersei’s season 1 look.

At the same time, the wedding dress contains a very subtle callback to Sansa’s Tourney dress from season one since the base colour of the gold-accented brocade is a pale lavender very similar to the season 1 dress. In a way, the use of the lavender colour is a cruel appropriation of this romantic dress (which incidentally also sports an embroidered direwolf like the wedding dress). The Tourney dress represent Sansa’s romanticism and her love of Chivalric Romance (x) - but now that romanticism has been put into a golden Lannister cage where marriage is not a union of lovers but a cynic power move against her family.

Another thing I noticed upon my re-watch of the wedding scene is how Sansa’s dress visually matches Joffrey’s opulent costume in terms of both colour and fabric. I’ve previously written about how matching clothes can be used to convey political and familial unity in the case of the Tyrells. In this case, however, the visual match between Sansa’s and Joffrey’s costumes signals domination rather than unity. 

In this context, the way that Sansa’s and Tyrion’s costumes don’t match is also meaningful. While Sansa is wearing gold-and-lavender brocade, Tyrion is wearing a tunic in oxblood leather. They clash visually, standing next to each other at the altar. However, after Sansa has been garbed in the red-gold Lannister bridal cloak, the dark red accent of the cloak suddenly makes her costume match Tyrion’s. Once again, this is not a visual statement of unity but rather of domination. With the cloaking of the bride, Tyrion (and through him House Lannister) takes possession of Sansa. She is now their property, bound to them permanently through the bonds of matrimony.

Sansa’s wedding costume also includes another element that harks back to her earlier romantic self - the lion medallion that Joffrey gave her as a love token in season 1 (he was insincere but to Sansa it was a gesture straight out of the chivalric romances she loved so much). Now this symbol of romantic love has been subverted into yet another message of domination, of ownership.

Embroidery

As we can see, the shape, the fabric and the colour of a costume can carry a lot of meaning. However, Clapton adds yet another narrative layer in the form of an embroidered band that wraps around the bodice and acts as a symbolic cage in the same manner that the dress itself functions as a material cage that envelops and restricts Sansa’s body. Clapton uses embroidery extensively in her costume design as a narrative element:

“The embroidery is a subliminal way to tell someone’s story,” says Michele Clapton (Hollywood Reporter)

When it comes to the embroidery Clapton co-operates with the embroiderer Michele Carragher, who creates countless beaded embellishments for the costumes of the show. In the case of Sansa’s wedding dress, Clapton and Carragher designed a piece of embroidery that uses the heraldry of several noble Houses to tell the story of Sansa’s parentage and her subsequent entrapment by the Lannisters. Thus, the entire piece makes up a story in itself, written across the body of an unwilling child-bride. 

“Obviously we imagined that the wedding dress has been commissioned by Cersei and the Lannisters for Sansa, and so the embroidery would have come from Cersei’s mind. We guessed that it wouldn’t be romantic or lovely and girly and pretty with dainty flowers, but a real strong message of dominance, saying that we own you now, Sansa. (Carragher, Winter Is Coming)

The story starts at the back of the band with a symbolic representation of Sansa’s parentage:

“For the wedding band, I started at the back of the waist with some Stark direwolves and Tully fish entwined that represent Sansa’s parentage.”  (Carragher, Winter Is Coming)

The band cross over itself on the front of the bodice where Carragher added the Lannister lion to the unfolding narrative:

“Then, as we move to the side, the Lannister lion is tangling with the direwolf and emerging on top, representing Sansa being seduced and then controlled by members of the house of Lannister. As it moves up the center, there’s a central ascending lion that’s got a Baratheon-like crown, a nod to Joffrey’s parentage.” (Carragher, Winter Is Coming) 

The story culminates at the back of her neck where the band morphs into a high and stiff collar, that looks rather uncomfortable:

“At the back neck, the Lannister lion is stamped onto it, representing how the Lannisters now have total ownership over this girl who was once a Stark.”  (Carragher, Winter Is Coming)


This is an ostentatious mark of ownership - Clapton herself calls it a “stamp” but one could just as well call it a “brand”. It is a symbolic marking of ownership - a statement of domination that has all the subtlety of a sledgehammer to the face.

The Pomegranate

Apart from the heraldic sigils of Houses Stark, Tully and Lannister, Michele Carragher also includes another symbol: the Pomegranate. 

The dress colour was still very much Sansa Stark and the embroidery had pale golden tones but woven through the story are ripe red pomegranates, the red colour symbolising the growing Lannister influence over her. (Michele Carragher)

Carragher interprets the deep red colour of the pomegranates as a symbol of Lannister influence due to the colour - and it looks as though she’s used either garnets or ruby swarovski crystals for the beaded embroidery.

I find Carragher’s interpretation rather curious because the pomegranate is one of the most ancient symbols in the world and it is invested with religious meaning in a great many cultures - from the ancient cities of Sumer to Judaism, Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam and Christianity. The oldest depiction of the pomegranate in the arts date was found in the city of Uruk in ancient Sumer and dates back more than 5,000 years (x). It was connected to the cult of Ishtar/Innana, goddess of love, sex, fertility.

Throughout the Mediterranean, Near Eastern and Middle Eastern world, the pomegranate has been revered as an ancient and potent symbol of fertility, regeneration and marriage:

“People use whatever is at hand to express their religious beliefs,"says Frank A. Salamone, an authority on religious symbols and a professor at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y. Centuries ago, in the Fertile Crescent, where so many religions arose, the pomegranate was at hand. By its very nature, it lent itself to religious symbolism.

"The pomegranate is red, and so is blood,” Salamone says. “It has a lot of seeds and is an obvious symbol of fertility.” It’s beautiful, strong and delicate, and its juice has healing properties, he says. “It says a lot of different things all at once. People bring meaning to it.” (Prof. Frank A. Salamone)

The pomegranate tree is considered to have originated in the in Persia (Iran) and its connection with notions of fertility is intimately connected with the advent and spread of agriculture. It’s status as a symbol of fertility was most likely transmitted through a kind of cross-cultural pollination along with the tree as it was exported East to China and West to Egypt, Turkey, North Africa, Greece and Rome.

While it is a fertility symbol in many cultures, the fruit also became associated with Death and Resurrection in Greek and Roman mythology. Most famously in the myth of Persephone, daughter of the fertility goddess Demeter. Persephone was a vegetation goddess like Demeter but according to myth she was abducted by Hades, the God of the Underworld. Demeter went into mourning and all plant life died so Zeus commanded Hades to release her daughter. However, Hades had tricked Persephone into eating six pomegranate seeds and so she was forced to spend six months of the year as Queen of the Underworld and the remaining six months above ground as a goddess of spring. The myth of Persephone is essentially an allegorical retelling of the changing of the seasons - and thus the pomegranate is not just connected to fertility (spring) but also to death (winter) and resurrection (the re-emergence of spring).

However, the pomegranate as a symbol of death and resurrection is also connected to another mythical figure: Adonis, the lover of Venus, the Roman goddess of love and sex. In the Metamorphoses, the Roman poet Ovid recounts the tale of Adonis who is slain on a hunt and the grief-stricken Venus creates the anemone flower, red like a pomegranate in memory of him:

When from the heights she saw the lifeless body lying in its own blood, she leapt down, tearing her clothes, and tearing at her hair as well, and beat at her breasts with fierce hands, complaining to the fates. “And yet not everything is in your power” she said. “Adonis, there shall be an everlasting token of my grief, and every year an imitation of your death will complete a re-enactment of my mourning. But your blood will be changed into a flower…” So saying, she sprinkled the blood with odorous nectar: and, at the touch, it swelled up, as bubbles emerge in yellow mud. In less than an hour, a flower, of the colour of blood, was created such as pomegranates carry, that hide their seeds under a tough rind. But enjoyment of it is brief: for, lightly clinging, and too easily fallen, the winds deflower it, which are likewise responsible for its name, windflower: anemone’ (Source)

According to myth, Adonis was raised by Persephone in the Underworld - but the figure has much older roots in the Sumerian story of Innana and Dumuzid. Adonis is thus very likely connected to Dying-and-Rising archetype, which characterizes a number of male fertility gods in the Middle Eastern and Mediterranean region of during Antiquity.

Christianity also appropriated the symbolism of Fertility and Resurrection associated with the pomegranate into its iconography:

In Christian art the pomegranate, often split and showing the seeds, was interpreted as a symbol of fertility, hope of immortality, and the Resurrection. The infant Jesus is frequently seen in paintings and sculpture presenting the pomegranate to his mother. In the last of the famous Unicorn tapestries at The Cloisters the symbolic meaning of marriage and fertility is illustrated by showing the Unicorn chained to the pomegranate tree, with the red seeds of a bursting fruit spilling on him. (Hildegard Schneider)

So the pomegranates on Sansa’s wedding dress has a very old and rich symbolic history - and the connection between the pomegranate and fertility is very apt in this context since the Lannisters intend for Sansa to bear fruit in her marriage in the form of a Lannister-Stark child through which they can claim the North.

Even more interesting is the fact that Sansa has her very own pomegranate symbolism in GRRM’s text. After Petyr Baelish spirits Sansa away to the Fingers, he offers her pomegranates and other fruits during a private conversation where he’s imparting his particular brand of wisdom:

Grisel reappeared before he could say more, balancing a large platter. She set it down between them. There were apples and pears and pomegranates, some sad-looking grapes, a huge blood orange. The old woman had brought a round of bread as well, and a crock of butter. Petyr cut a pomegranate in two with his dagger, offering half to Sansa. “You should try and eat, my lady.” “Thank you, my lord.” Pomegranate seeds were so messy; Sansa chose a pear instead, and took a small delicate bite. It was very ripe. The juice ran down her chin.

…

“In King’s Landing, there are two sorts of people. The players and the pieces.”

“And I was a piece?” She dreaded the answer.

“Yes, but don’t let that trouble you. You’re still half a child. Every man’s a piece to start with, and every maid as well. Even some who think they are players.” He ate another seed. “Cersei, for one. She thinks herself sly, but in truth she is utterly predictable. Her strength rests on her beauty, birth, and riches. Only the first of those is truly her own, and it will soon desert her. I pity her then. She wants power, but has no notion what to do with it when she gets it. Everyone wants something, Alayne. And when you know what a man wants you know who he is, and how to move him." 

…

Lord Petyr dismissed him with a wave, and returned to the pomegranate again as Oswell shuffled down the steps. ”Tell me, Alayne—which is more dangerous, the dagger brandished by an enemy, or the hidden one pressed to your back by someone you never even see?“

"The hidden dagger.” (ASoS, Sansa VI) 

Baelish then starts to eat a blood orange as he continues to talk, steadily guiding Sansa through his machinations until she realizes that it was Olenna Tyrell who poisoned Joffrey:

He tilted his chin back and squeezed the blood orange, so the juice ran down into his mouth. “I love the juice but I loathe the sticky fingers,” he complained, wiping his hands. “Clean hands, Sansa. Whatever you do, make certain your hands are clean.” (ASoS, Sansa VI)

The conversation goes on as Baelish relates exactly how he manipulated the Tyrells into doing what he wanted.

This is not just a conversation over fruit where Baelish instructs his new pupil in the subtleties of the game of thrones. It is a temptation scenario where he offers Sansa a fruit associated with temptation as he intends to mold her into his own image. Like Hades, Baelish tempts Sansa with the pomegranate but unlike Persephone, Sansa refuses the fruit. 

Sansa REFUSES the pomegranate! This is very important because it foreshadows her eventually rejecting Baelish and his nefarious ambitions.

This temptation scenario is lent even more symbolic weight if we consider the hypothesis that the Forbidden Fruit in the Garden of Eden might not have been an apple but a pomegranate! (x) This interpretation is still somewhat controversial but if the Forbidden Fruit was indeed a pomegranate then the Temptation of Eve does have an interesting parallel with the Temptation of Persephone.

I have been unable to find any confirmation that the pomegranates on Sansa’s wedding dress are meant to have a deeper meaning than an association to the Lannister red. However, Carragher develops her creations in collaboration with Clapton and she does quite a bit of historical research:

For “Game of Thrones,” Carragher often spends as long thinking about a piece as she does making it. First, she confers with Clapton about each character’s narrative arc and the costumes Clapton has designed for them. Then Carragher does historical research in museums near her home, in East London. After a month of planning, she ships her materials to the show’s Belfast production studios, where she works six days a week, twelve hours a day, embellishing a season’s worth of costumes. (The NewYorker)

Thus, it is not implausible that adorning a wedding dress with an age old symbol of fertility and marriage is not entirely coincidental on the part of the designers!
trail.content:
I’ve previously written a series of essays that analyse Sansa Stark’s narrative arc in Game of Thrones - during season 1 (Part 1, Part 2, Part 3, Part 4, Part 5, Part 6) and during season 2 (Part 7, Part 8, Part 9, Part 10) and now during season 3 (Part 11, Part 12, Part 13, Part 14, Part 15, Part 16). This post is the 17th installment in this series and the last one that deals with Sansa’s season 3 arc. 

In this post, I’m going to take a closer look at Sansa’s costumes during the season with a special emphasis on her spectacular golden wedding gown since her season 3 arc revolves around her political value as Robb’s heir apparent and there are several plots aimed at securing the Key to the North through marriage. It is also a costume that is inscribed with a lot of narrative and symbolic meaning that subtly enriches her story and her characterization.

Costume design is an integral aspect of the visual language of cinema and television - and especially on Game of Thrones since costume designer Michele Clapton approaches the costumes in terms of story-telling.

I always try to make the clothes visually tell something. (FIDM Museum Blog)

I always try to tell that story — the costumes for me are narrative and you should be able to look at them [the characters] and understand where they are mentally in their journey. (Insider)

I love to try and indicate the emotional state of characters through their costumes, and also to indicate their influence over other characters and courts. Sometimes this says so much more than words. (SPIN)

Thus, the costumes are incredibly important in this show and it is worth paying attention to them because every single detail is meaningful:

Everything – even a fashion choice – has meaning on “Game of Thrones.” In this cutthroat world where men fight for the Iron Throne and the women yield a different kind of power, a choice of fabric or a different cut of cloth can be a political statement, costume designer Michele Clapton told TODAY.com.(Today)

Even in real life, clothing has always had symbolic and communicative value through which people signal social and cultural positions. In short, fashion and dress codes place people within a given culture. Garments function as non-verbal signs that that can be interpreted differently depending on the context, situation or culture (x). That is doubly so for costume design since it its entire raison d’etre is to support and enrich the story that is told.

THE SARTORIAL EVOLUTION OF SANSA STARK

As said, Sansa’s golden wedding dress will be the primary focus of this post - both because of its symbolic value but also because it is markedly different from the rest of her costumes during season 3. However, before I start analyzing the wedding dress it will be instructive to take a look at how she generally dresses during season 3 because the colour, cut and embellishment of the wedding dress stands in stark contrast to the rest of her costumes.

The costumes are an important part of the story-telling but they are an especially important part of Sansa’s character since she’s the only character that is repeatedly shown to make her own clothes! This is something that Michele Clapton emphasizes in several interviews:

“She expresses herself through her ability to embroider and stitch,” Clapton told Buzzfeed. “We’ve always used that as something that Sansa expresses her feelings through—her embroidery and depictions on her costumes, and through shade and color.” (Looper)

Costume is important to Sansa—she sees it as a way of communicating with people, to show her aspirations. And we very quickly see her develop.She starts to adapt—she has certain people she’s impressed by. (TIME)

So let’s take a closer look at Sansa Stark’s season 3 costumes - both in relation to where she is politically and emotionally in season 3 but also in relation to how her costumes have evolved from season 1. 

Season 1

When we first meet Sansa Stark in Winterfell, her costumes reflect both her Northern roots with the heavy fabrics, the sensible layers that insulates against the cold climate (like the linen shirt underneath the dress), the embroidery that the Northern women practice to while away the time - as well as her youthful innocence, which is very much reflected in the use of the baby blue colour that dominate almost all of her Northern costumes. 

Clapton chose dark blue as a common element in the Stark costumes, which reflect the harsher Northern climate:

We have a lot of blues and grays, murkier colors that seemed right for the harsh northern climates. The Starks represent a warm family unit, so the blues of their costumes are rather warm. But within the family, the various personalities are reflected in what they wear. For example, Sansa is in a slightly cooler blue. (CostumeVault) 

Interestingly, Clapton also uses this light blue as a way to emphasize that Sansa is somewhat out of sync with the rest of her family. This becomes especially clear when the Starks line up to greet King Robert in the first episode. While the rest of the Starks are dressed in dark blues and greys, Sansa is exclusively dressed in the light baby blue - even the fur on her cloak is light blue! This makes Sansa stand out like a sore thumb among the Stark household. Considering how Clapton approaches costume design in terms of both story-telling and characterization, this choice is no coincidence.

She is, in a sense, a bit isolated within in her own family given how none of her siblings share her interests, not to mention that gender norms also play a role in relation to this issue (x). While this isn’t something that the show really delves into at the level of the text, the costuming clearly articulates a sense of isolation within the family when it comes to Sansa - and that is probably one of the reasons why she’s so excited to travel to King’s Landing.

Sansa’s costumes changes when she arrives in King’s Landing. A significant costume is the lavender dress that she first wears at the Hand’s Tourney. This dress represents a sartorial amalgam of the Northern and the King’s Landing style. The lavender colour occupy a mid-point between Sansa’s Northern blue and the dusty rose colours that the women wear at the court in King’s Landing. However, the fabric is similar to her Northern dress and the embroidery not only includes her House Sigil (the Direwolf) but the leafy vines that climb the sides of the dress are rather similar to the embroidery on her Winterfell feast dress (picture at the far right in the collage below)

The most conspicuous detail is the neckline, which is not only significantly lower than her Northern dresses but it is also embellished with cloth roses - an completely new element in Sansa’s personal iconography (x). This dress also marks the beginning of Sansa’s slow transition from a child to a young girl at the cusp of maidenhood.

Later in the season, Sansa’s Northern dresses are completely discarded - and she is now dressed in the kimono-style of light-weight fabric like the ones that Cersei wears.

However, it is also important to note that she only starts wearing these Cersei-inspired costumes after she has fallen completely within the power of the Lannisters.

Where a character comes from is indicated through the color and cut of the costume. When we first see Sansa [Sophie Turner], she wears things in a Stark way — very well, but they are slightly clumsy and the cloth is rather homespun. As she comes to King’s Landing, her progression is influenced by Cersei [Lena Headey] and her costumes shift. After Cersei does the awful thing of sanctioning the death of Ned Stark [Sansa’s father], Sansa is stuck — you can see her frozen in time. She’s looking like someone who has just killed her father. And then we will see her progression as she slowly withdraws from the look. (LATimes) 

A very important detail of these Cersei-like costumes is the fact that they don’t fit Sansa at all! They are much too large and she’s practically drowning in them. This is a very important detail:

“A lot of people said her costume doesn’t fit. Well, of course it doesn’t! She’s a young girl trying to copy someone,” explained Clapton. “Not everyone wears things brilliantly or beautifully, or has the access to do that.
